Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2011 08:49PM solange49 wrote: Hi Posy, I know you're going through a scary time waiting onyour path results to determine your stage, etc. I was diagnosed in may with stage 3c invasive Ductal cancer. It was very scary to hear. My tumor was 5 cm and I had several lymph node involvement plus a spot on my cheast wall. I have a great Onc who gave me 5 months of chemo, the did another pet scan after my chemo ended. It showed that chemo had reduced the cancer by over 50%! I will have my double mastectomy on Monday and radiation to follow. My prognosis is good. So...even in later stages there's always hope and medicine has come a long way and going further soon I pray! Let us know how you are, Hugs Diana.
Posts.Title: Coping with the wait for the Stage TectonicShift Beeb75

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 08:48PM solange49 wrote: Stephanie- thx for the nice compliment on my pic. :) My hair is beginning to grow back...woot woot! You're right....staging is a guess untill after surgery. I had chemo first. My PET scan afterwards showed an over 50% decrease in the size of my tumor and lymph node involvement. I just had my bilateral mastectomy on Monday. My surgeon called today with path results. She said 13 of 15 nodes removed were positive and my tumor was 6 cm. I'll have radiation when I recover. Posy- I'm still thinking of you. Yes, your ER, PR, and HER status are very important things to know and will determine your treatment. You're on the path. The more you know about your type of cancer...the better in making an informed decision in your healing process. Diana
Posts.Title: Coping with the wait for the Stage TectonicShift Beeb75

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 03:07AM solange49 wrote: Hi KD2011, I'm so sorry you are going through all this. You've been through quite an ordeal. When I saw your photos it reminded me of what my right breast looked like. It was swollen, purplish, had a bruised appearance. It also felt warm to the touch, skin thickening, and my nipple was inverted. It just seemed to appear overnight. I had a mammo and ultrasound the next day (after a clean mammo 5 months earlier). The radiologist told me it appeared to be IBC but ordered a biopsy to be sure. Well I had the biopsy and I was diagnosed with Invasive Ductal Carcenoma. I had a lot of the symptoms of IBC but not all...such as the orange peel appearance of the breast. I agree with the other ladies. You need to find a good gyn or breast surgeon that will be knowledgeable and find out what's going on. Your biopsies might not have been done correctly. Please keep us updated on how you are, Hugs, Diana

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2011 08:36PM solange49 wrote: That's great that you're getting it checked out. :) I too had a little dimpling and felt a lump which seemed to appear overnight. I had a "clean" mammo 5 months prior. I had been having them every six months for over two years due to micro calcifications. After I discovered my lump, the biopsy was performed. I was diagnosed with stage IIIc cancer. I wish mine was discovered sooner. More than likely yours will be nothing to worry about , but it's better to be on the safe side. Good luck to you! Hugs, Diana

Posts.Content: solange49 wrote: Hi ladies, I posted a little over a week ago under "question" and had some great responses. Since then I've had my follow up visit with my Onc after my BMX yesterday. She told me what I didn't want to hear. Since I had so many positive lymph nodes she said I would need more chemo. I had four rounds of A/C followed by four dd rounds of Taxol prior to my surgery. Now I have to have eight rounds of Gemcitabine/Carboplatin before I can even begin radiation. I know it could be alot worse but I am so bummed out by this news. I really hoped I was through with chemo. Have any of you ladies been on this chemo cocktail? What can I expect now? I'm so sick of this. I would really appreciate any comments. Diana Dx 5/19/2011, IDC, Stage IIIC, Grade 2, 13/15 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 5/30/2011 AC + T (Taxol) Chemotherapy 5/30/2011 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Gemzar (gemcitabine), Taxol (paclitaxel) Surgery 10/24/2011 Lymph node removal: Right; Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 11/14/2011 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Gemzar (gemcitabine) Radiation Therapy 2/20/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 4/30/2012 Surgery 9/14/2012 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap, Free TRAM flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap, Free TRAM flap Dx 10/31/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 2/27/2013 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 10/19/2014 Navelbine (vinorelbine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Repost: please help solange49 Romansma

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2011 11:53PM solange49 wrote: Hi Many, your diagnosis and mine are very similar. I am still undergoing chemo and will have my BMX and rads afterward. I had a PET scan at the beginning but not certain how many positive nodes I have. My Onc said she would not be sure of the amount until my surgeon went in. Have you visited the "3+ years out" forum. I enjoy going to that one. It gives me hope for long term survival. Speaking of hope...I just finished a wonderful book that I would recommend to any woman with breast cancer. It's called "There's No Place Like Hope" written by Vickie Girard. She was diagnosed in 1992 with advanced stage IV breast cancer. Although she's no longer with us... She lived for 15 years! Her story and spirit inspired me. :) I have read several books since being diagnosed. Vickie's jouney and message was so uplifting. It brought me to tears. We need all the hope and encouragement we can get right now. There are also several good survivor stories on the Susan Komen site. Diana

Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 09:26AM solange49 wrote: Hi 3beans, I hate to hear you are going through this horrible waiting game. I can relate. I thinks it's great that you're being proactive when it comes to your health. A little about my diagnosis. Before my cancer was discovered, I had been having diagnostic mammos and ultrasounds every six months for 2 years due to calcifications they were watching. I went faithfully. In late Dec of last year I had a "clear" mammo and ultrasound. Then on Mothers Day this year I was taking a shower I noticed the whole right side of my breast was swollen and the lump could be felt easily. After going to my gyn the next day, another mammo and ultrasound was performed ( at a different breast center I might add ). It showed the 5 cm lump and abnormalities. My biopsy was done a couple of days later, then I had to wait about 3 days for the results. It came back IDC. After my pet scan and pathology report, I was diagnosed as stage 3c. It's grade 2 and I'm Her 2 neg which means I don't have a fast growing cancer. I feel my lump should have been caught 5 months earlier. I might not be in a later stage. I also blame myself for not being more diligent doing more self exams and putting too much faith in the medical community that were supposed to be monitoring me. I hope I didn't scare you with my story. We can't be too persistent when it comes to our health. And since 80% of biopsies turn out benign... I pray that you're in that percentage. I know the wait is horrible but we're here for you anytime. :) Hugs, Diana
Posts.Title: more symptoms and 2 weeks to specialist 3beans Lavender250

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2011 05:44PM solange49 wrote: Hi again Lesley, yes it won't be an easy road but you can do it! It's overwhelming at first. Try to take one day at a time and be kind to yourself. I have always been a very positive person but I have damn down days and that's to be expected. That's good news that your bs doesn't think theres any lymph node involvement. I know it's hard to hear the mastectomy recommendation. I remember how I felt. I just had my surgery Monday. It will be a little easier on you when you have more info such as ER/PR status....etc. As far as doing anything legally.....personally I say go for it! I related my personal experience in a previous post. I am not a "sue happy" person either but I totally feel that there was negligance there. If our medical professionals aren't ever held accountable for their actions...then think of what could happen! Yes, by all means...put your health first, but do make them accountable! Just my opinion. Keep coming here. It helps to be able to have other women to talk to that are in our "shoes". Share your story. I have been so touched by the support of other women here, my friends, family...and complete strangers that have come up to me. It's a road no one would have ever chosen...but ....you'll never feel so "loved" Hugs, Diana

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 05:20PM solange49 wrote: Hi Lesley...wow I totally understand your anger and you have every right to be! I had "cystic" breasts and my dr had me going for a diagnostic mammo and ultrasound every six months because of this. I went faithfully and felt I did everything right on my end. After a "clean" mammo & ultrasound in late Dec. of last year I found a large lump in my left breast 5 months later in May. After having a biopsy, PET scan, etc. I was diagnosed with stage IIIC invasive Ductal carcinoma. I was so angry with the system and felt very let down. My cancer should have been caught so much earlier!! I have gone through chemo and just had a double mastectomy 2 days ago. They were not able to do reconstruction yet unfortunately due to my stage. So I'll have to wait. Path showed 13 of 15 nodes were positive and tumor was 6cm. I may have to have more chemo before radiation. I'll find out when I return for my follow up. I know it could have been worse but it could have also been better. Hang in there. I'll be thinking of you and praying for B-9 results. Keep us posted, Diana

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2011 04:27PM solange49 wrote: Clevelandgirl99, hi I'm so sorry you are having to go through all this. I know from experience the waiting can be excruciating. You didn't mention what was found for your dr to request a biopsy. I won't go into detail about my story, only that I so wish that my dr had been diligent enough to order a biopsy on my breast. If they had have...I might not be a late stage IIIc that I am. It would have been caught so much earlier. It is worth it! Please know that , yes 80% of biopsies are B9. But it's so much better being safe, than sorry. Praying for good results for you, Hugs, Diana

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2011 09:01PM solange49 wrote: Yes Gem4jewels I agree with Rennasus. I will tell you a little about my story...not to scare you I hope..but to be made aware. I'm 49 and I've always faithfully had my mammos every year. About 3 years ago a mammo detected micro calcifications in both breasts and was then informed they wanted to keep an eye on any changes and was told to start coming in every six months for a diagnostic mammo and ultrasound. I did so. Every six months I went. I had my last mammo and ultrasound in late December of last year. They said they saw no changes and informed me to schedule again in 6 months. Well...on Mothers day I had just taken a shower and when drying off I noticed my right breast was swollen on one side, a bruised apperance and felt a lump. I scheduled an appt with my gyn the next day. He was so concerned he sent me for another mammo and ultrasound and it showed the 5 cm lump. I then had a biopsy in which I was told several days later that it was cancer. My PET scan was done and I was staged at IIIc. I had just had a "clean mammo" five months prior now I have a more advanced cancer with lymph node involvement. I feel my cancer should have been detected so much sooner. And If I had to do it all over again I would have asked for a biopsy. I still stress the importance of regular mammos to my friends but now I know that they are not foolproof and since I've been diagnosed...I have read other stories like mine. If you have any concern ...don't wait 6 months...get a biopsy. Again...I I hope this doesn't scare you and please know that 80% of biopsies turn up benign. Yes, the stats are in your favor. :). keep us posted! Hugs, Diana
Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow on Right Breast & Rib Pain gem4jewels solange49

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 11:43PM solange49 wrote: Hi everyone. I haven't posted due to all the posts being a bit overwhelming to me. But you all have been in my thoughts and prayers. My surgeon called me earlier and informed me that she removed 15 lymph nodes and 13 of those were cancerous. My tumor was 6 cm. I'm glad I made the decision to have my left breast (the good one lol ) removed as well because the path results showed numerous problems with it. There's a possibility I may have to have more chemo before radiation but I won't know until I go for my Onc appt. I hope not...but I'll do more if needed. It's been hard looking at my bare chest... but I'm here and that's really what counts. I'll have reconstruction when my dr gives me the go ahead. Hugs and thinking of you guys, Diana

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2011 04:39AM solange49 wrote: Hi everyone, although I haven't been posting, you're all in my thoughts and prayers. I've been pretty down lately and just ready to feel halfway normal again. After finishing all my chemo treatments, my onc told me not to get my hopes up about having immediate reconstruction after my BMX due to my stage of cancer and needing radiation afterwards. I had my PET scan Monday and met my my surgeon today. The good news is that my chemo reduced the size of my tumor and lymph node involvement by at least 50 %. the bad news is I'll have to wait a few months for reconstruction. I was really disappointed to hear that. I had hoped to wake up with something. I'll just have to get used to the idea. The office will call me tomorrow to schedule my surgery. Dawn- I'm so sry to hear about your setback. My thoughts and prayers are with you. Gamergirl- I'm sorry as well to learn your news. I know you were not expecting this at all. I went through chemo and was scared at first. But it's doable. There are so many good meds to manage the side effects that we didn't have years ago. We're here for you! Hugs Ann- I'll be thinking of you tomorrow and saying a prayer for an easy surgery for you. Hugs

Please be hoping for me as well. :). Diana

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2011 05:05PM solange49 wrote: Hi Denise, it's great to see someone else from AR. I'm in Little Rock. :). I'm sry about your MRI. Maybe your PET scan will be better! Have you received the results yet? I'm expecting a call today to schedule my surgery. I'm wanting the week of the 24th. I will be having it at Baptist Hospital. Do you see your Onc tomorrow? Diana
Posts.Title: Any October 2011 Surgeries out there want to wait together? gamergirl GrandmaV

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2011 10:05PM solange49 wrote: Hi Etherize, I'm so sorry you are going through this. Please try not to be too hard on yourself. Cycle-path is right. Your lump may have not been detectable even if you had been having regular mammos. I had been going to have mammos faithfully. I found my lump on my own after having a "clean" mammo 5 months prior. My lump was already 5 centimeters and I was diagnosed with stage 3 C cancer! Mammos are such a wonderful tool in this fight to detect cancer...but unfortunately, it's not foolproof. You have come to the right place and I pray for good results from your biopsy. You've already shown how much of a fighter you are! Please let us know how you are, Hugs, Diana
Posts.Title: I think it's going to be bad news etherize cimo37

Posts.Content: solange49 wrote: Hi all, My name is Jacques. I am the husband of Diana. I'm writing to let you know that we lost our beloved Diana on Sunday, February 8 at approximately 12:30 AM. She battled cancer valiantly for 3 3/4 years. She will be greatly missed by a score of family and friends whose lives she touched. I consider myself blessed and honored to have been able to spend our lives together. The world has lost a wonderful daughter, mother, grandmother, friend, and colleague. I wish you all courage, strength, and peace as you continue your cancer journeys. God bless, Jacques (Edited by Mods to remove personal identifying information. We strongly recommend not posting personal information on a public forum, for your own privacy and security) Diana Dx 5/19/2011, IDC, Stage IIIC, Grade 2, 13/15 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 5/30/2011 AC + T (Taxol) Chemotherapy 5/30/2011 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Gemzar (gemcitabine), Taxol (paclitaxel) Surgery 10/24/2011 Lymph node removal: Right; Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 11/14/2011 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Gemzar (gemcitabine) Radiation Therapy 2/20/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 4/30/2012 Surgery 9/14/2012 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap, Free TRAM flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap, Free TRAM flap Dx 10/31/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 2/27/2013 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 10/19/2014 Navelbine (vinorelbine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Heartbreaking News - Diana Payne solange49 dlb823

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 04:22PM solange49 wrote: Bak94 - thanks for replying. Hope you're feeling today. Summer colds suck especially when you're dealing with chemo, etc. I just finished having my chemo day and as you said...my Onc said she thought it was highly likely my BS would delay reconstruction for awoke. I'm really bummed out to hear this. Ive been having more down days than usual and it was just one more thing. I know it could be worse though. Thanks for letting me vent, Diana
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 09:41AM - edited Aug 30, 2011 09:44AM by solange49 Hi everyone, I don't post very often but so excited to know that I have just two more chemos to go. I began on may 30th. Four DD AC then four DD Taxol. The dose dense taxol has been a little tougher than I thought. I have run fever for a few days after each one. And the bone pain! Ugh. I'm sure most of that is from the neulasta shot. I also began physical therapy for a shoulder problem I'm having. It hasnt been a good year health wise for me. :) I've always been so healthy before all this. I'm just so ready to get this chemo behind me. I'm doing research now on what type of reconstruction I'd like to go with. Then rads after that. I'd like to hear from you guys to see how you're holding up, hugs, Diana Diagnosis: 5/19/2011, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIc, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2-
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 10:25PM solange49 wrote: Margie- No I haven't tried a Swedish massage for the bone pain. Thanks I may do that. :) I am sooooo glad I only have two more chemos to go! Bak94- I'm not sure if I'm going to be able to have my reconstruction before rad. I have chemo on Thursday and my onc and I are supposed to talk about my surgery. She wanted to wait until I'm close to the end of chemo. I'm ready to find out my options and get on with it! I may have to wait as well though. I'm just anxious to find out so I'll be prepared. I've also been reading about Diep. So sorry about your cold. Hope you feel better soon. :) Diana
